body:
### Steps to reproduce

I tried to run `spack install libiconv`. It failed because it couldn't find a working C compiler.

Before I start, I have a hacky workaround that lets me build. Hopefully, this hack will explain what's going on. Basically, SPACK insists on using "cc" or "CC" as the compiler, regardless of what I put in `compilers.yaml` and `packages.yaml`

The end result is that all packages fail to build because "the c compiler cannot produce executables."

Here's my hack:
```
$ tail -4 /global/u2/s/sbrandt/spack/lib/spack/env/gcc/gcc
full_command_list=$(echo $full_command_list|perl -p -e 's{^cc}{/opt/cray/pe/gcc/9.3.0/bin/gcc}')
full_command_list=$(echo $full_command_list|perl -p -e 's{^CC}{/opt/cray/pe/gcc/9.3.0/bin/g++}')
echo "ff: $full_command_list" > ~/.spack-cc.txt
IFS="$lsep"; exec $full_command_list
```

Here's my compilers.yaml. Note that, by default, spack seems to get this wrong. Instead of "cc: cc" it should have "cc: gcc", but it doesn't matter what I set here, it tries to compile with "cc".
```
$ cat ~/.spack/cray/compilers.yaml
compilers:
- compiler:
    spec: gcc@9.3.0
    paths:
      cc: gcc
      cxx: g++
      f77: gfortran
      fc: gfortran
    flags: {}
    operating_system: sles15
    target: any
    modules:
    - PrgEnv-gnu
    - gcc/9.3.0
    environment: {}
    extra_rpaths: []
```
Here's my packages.yaml
```
$ cat ~/.spack/packages.yaml
packages:
    all:
        compiler:
        - gcc@9.3.0
```
Note that it doesn't matter whether I say `spack install libiconv` or `spack install libiconv%gcc@9.3.0`, spack still uses just `cc` and `CC` to build.

BTW, here's my spack version:
```
$ git log | cat -
commit 285548588f533338cc5493a7ba492f107e714794
Author: Todd Gamblin <tgamblin@llnl.gov>
Date:   Fri Nov 5 17:11:18 2021 -0700

    Update CHANGELOG.md for 0.17.0
```

I'm really baffled as to why I need to do this hack. Thanks.
